properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong wind gusts Friday morning. Strong westerly wind gusts up to 80 km/h are possible beginning overnight. The strong winds will begin to ease later Friday morning. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions due to high winds. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-22T07:49:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-21T15:50:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3719333707.2019
Area: Picton - Sandbanks Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall accumulations of near 15 cm expected. Locally higher totals are possible. Locations: Gander, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, and inland portions of the Bay d'Espoir Highway. Time span: late Thursday morning until near midnight Thursday night. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop Thursday morning and become heavy at times early Thursday afternoon. Snow is forecast to taper off to flurries or drizzle overnight Thursday. Substantial amounts of heavy, wet snow are possible over some areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-21T18:03:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-21T02:04:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2352524434.2019
Area: Connaigre, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Gander and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall tonight into Thursday. Snow will begin tonight over portions of Northwestern Ontario spreading eastward towards the Quebec border by Thursday morning. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible by the time the snow ends on Thursday. Areas closer to the shores of Lake Superior may begin as rain and receive less snowfall, particularly areas east of Marathon. There remains uncertainty regarding the exact location of the highest snowfall amounts. Snowfall warnings may be required for some regions. This snowfall is due to a developing low pressure system that will track south of the region. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-21T19:12:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-21T03:13:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1697990257.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A few hours of freezing rain are expected Thursday night. Ice accretion amounts will range from 2 to 5 millimetres. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall and snowfall are expected. Total rainfall: 15 to 30 mm along the coast. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm inland and over higher terrain. Locations: Bay of Exploits and Bonavista North. Time span: midday today until midnight tonight. Remarks: Drizzle will transition to a mixture of rain and snow this afternoon, with snow primarily occurring inland and rain mainly at the coast. The wintry mix will change back to rain or drizzle over all areas after midnight. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions in the heavy, wet snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-22T06:41:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-21T14:42:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0970958905.2019
Area: Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow tonight and Thursday. Snow will begin near Lake Superior near midnight and spread eastward towards the Quebec border by Thursday morning. Snowfall amounts in the 15 to 20 cm range can be expected before the snow tapers off late Thursday or Thursday night. Areas closer to the shores of Lake Superior will receive slightly less snowfall as the precipitation will begin as rain and only change over to snow Thursday night. This snowfall is due to a developing low pressure system that will track south of the region. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-21T19:11:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-21T03:12:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1139567437.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected over some areas. Total snowfall: 4 to 8 cm, except 20 cm inland and over higher terrain. Locations: Terra Nova National Park to Clarenville. Time span: continuing until late this evening. Remarks: A mixture of rain and snow will transition to mainly snow this afternoon. The heaviest accumulations will occur inland and over higher elevations with lesser amounts along the coast. The snow is expected to change back to rain over all areas tonight. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix of rain and snow is expected. Total rainfall: 30 to 45 mm along the coast. Total snowfall: near 10 cm inland and over higher terrain. Locations: Bonavista and Burin Peninsulas. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Rain will continue over coastal areas today, but precipitation will be mixed with snow inland and over higher terrain. The snow will change back to rain this evening. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions and reduced visibilities in the heavy, wet snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Total rainfall: 40 to 70 mm. Locations: Avalon Peninsula. Time span: continuing until midnight tonight. Remarks: Downpours are possible this afternoon and evening. The rain may also mix with snow at times, mainly over northwestern sections of the Avalon Peninsula, where a couple centimetres could accumulate over higher elevations. The rain will ease after midnight tonight. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are forecast to develop later this morning and end by this evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: 100 km/h. Locations: Bonavista Peninsula. Time span: midnight tonight until early Friday morning. Remarks: Northeasterly winds will strengthen today with the strongest gusts occurring overnight tonight. Winds will gradually ease on Friday. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected over some areas. Total snowfall: 15 to 20 cm. Locations: mainly the Bay d'Espoir Highway area, with lesser amounts elsewhere. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Snow, heavy at times, will continue over the interior today with significant accumulations likely along the Bay d'Espoir Highway. The highest amounts will occur over elevated terrain. Precipitation will fall mainly as rain along the coast, though may mix with or change to snow this evening. In the Buchans area, precipitation is expected to occur mainly as snow, but with total accumulations less than 10 cm. Conditions will improve over all areas later this evening as the precipitation tapers off. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-22T02:00:39-00:00
